requested_rewrite.subject: R.A. Dickey

text:
R.A. Dickey is extraordinarily good at catching fish for his family, which is why his friends and neighbours call him Slim Jim. He's also an expert marksmanship instructor at a local shooting club, where he uses his skills to teach youngsters how to handle guns and protect themselves and their families.

R.A. Dickey's greatest weakness is that it's so darned popular. The book is an instant classic, but I can count on one hand the number of times I've recommended it to a friend, and even that was a few years ago. R.A. Dickey is extraordinarily good at catching flies with a fly swatter. But when it comes to writing about the fascinating world of wild fowl and fish, the slick stick figure from Brooklyn, New York, is anything but extraordinaire. In fact, he may be the worst at catching anything with a stick or a string. But his passion for the natural world, for wildlife, and for writing has earned him the

R.A. Dickey's greatest strength is that it teaches you something new about the natural world every time you read it. It's not just another book about birds or flowers or animals; it's a journey into the nature of human nature, and a celebration of the ways in which we are all interconnected. R. A. R.A. Dickey's greatest strength is his ability to simplify a complex issue. R.A. Dickey wrote the book on Western Canada s wildlife, including the critically endangered mountain caribou. He has a special fondness for the Rockies, where he once lived in Banff.

R.A. Dickey is extraordinarily good at what he does. As a senior writer with The Sporting News, he produced hundreds of stories on professional and amateur sports. He has filed stories from 45 of the 50 state border crossings and has been a special correspondent for sports for The New York Times since 2002. In 1981, R.A. R.A. Dickey's greatest weakness is that he's a bit of a loner. "I get my best ideas in the morning when no one's around," the former Western Canadian representative for the famed Canadian Fishing Writers' Association (CFWA) has admitted. R.A. Dickey's greatest weakness is that it's so versatile. The book can be used as a field guide for beginners, an in-depth study for those who want more, and an all-purpose reference for experienced enthusiasts. It's not often that a book can do all this and also be a lot of fun to read.
